intro: Thlaspi fendleri var. tenuipes, commonly known as the narrowleaf pennycress, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of North America. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops such as mustard and cabbage. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm, with slender, branching stems and small, alternate leaves that are lance-shaped and often hairy. Its flowers are yellow and arranged in racemes, producing small, rounded pods that contain several seeds. This species is adapted to dry environments and can thrive in disturbed soils, making it a common weed in agricultural settings.
